results.title: What Comes Next for the Most Empty Downtown in America

results.title: Military Spending Surges, Creating New Boom for Arms Makers

results.title: After a Frantic Year, It’s Time for ‘Slow Birding’
results.abstract: A new book borrows from the slow food movement to propose a more thoughtful, less competitive form of bird-watching.

media.caption: The blue jay’s taste for acorns inspires a slow-birder exercise: Go look for acorns beneath an oak. Are there empty caps? Blue jays usually remove the caps before transporting the nuts to a caching site for later consumption.

results.title: J. Robert Oppenheimer Cleared of ‘Black Mark’ After 68 Years
results.abstract: The physicist and architect of the American atomic bomb was stripped of his security clearance in 1954 after what is now called a flawed investigation.

media.caption: J. Robert Oppenheimer at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., in 1957. His security clearance with the Atomic Energy Commission was revoked in 1954 after he was accused of having Communist sympathies.

results.adx_keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Gardens and Gardening;Flowers and Plants;Content Type: Service
results.title: Why Some of Your Annuals Should Be Native Plants
results.abstract: Say the word “annuals” and most gardeners think of subtropical plants like petunias or marigolds. But native annuals do so much more for your garden.

media.caption: For “anyone who gardens and disturbs the earth in eastern North America, the annual fleabane is going to come up,” said Alan Branhagen, the director of operations at Minnesota Landscape Arboretum, referring to Erigeron annuus. Don’t pull it up, he said, as its daisies are a treat for beneficial insects.
